definitions: remove a veil or covering from something to show what is beneath
make something known or visible that was previously secret or hidden
examples: The mayor will unveil the new statue tomorrow afternoon
The bride unveiled her face after the ceremony ended
The company unveiled their latest smartphone at the conference
Scientists unveiled groundbreaking research about climate change yesterday

definitions: relax after a period of work or tension and become calm
undo or become undone after being wound up or twisted
examples: She likes to unwind with a book after work
Take a hot bath to unwind your tired muscles
Carefully unwind the rope from around the tree trunk
The fishing line unwound quickly as the fish swam

definitions: maintain or support something such as a law principle or decision
confirm or support a previous decision especially in a legal context
examples: Teachers must uphold high standards in the classroom daily
Citizens should uphold the values of democracy and freedom
The supreme court upheld the lower court's ruling yesterday
The board upheld their decision to close the factory

definitions: make someone feel happier more hopeful or more confident about life
raise something to a higher position or level through physical force
examples: Her kind words uplifted everyone during the difficult time
Music has the power to uplift the human spirit
Tectonic forces uplift mountain ranges over millions of years
The crane uplifted the heavy steel beams into position

definitions: transfer data or files from a computer or device to the internet or server
examples: Please upload your assignment to the course website tonight
She uploads new videos to her channel every Wednesday
It took hours to upload all the photos from vacation
The app automatically uploads your contacts to the cloud

definitions: pull a plant including its roots completely out of the ground
force someone to leave their home or familiar place often unwillingly
examples: The storm uprooted several trees in our front yard
Gardeners uproot weeds to keep the flower bed healthy
War uprooted thousands of families from their ancestral homes
The new job uprooted her from everything she knew

definitions: discharge liquid waste from the body through the urinary system
examples: Most adults urinate between six and eight times daily
The doctor asked him to urinate in the specimen cup
Pets need to be trained where to urinate properly
Some medications can affect how often you urinate daily

definitions: show people to their seats especially in a theater or church
cause or mark the start of something new or different
examples: Volunteers usher guests to their seats before the concert
The wedding party hired someone to usher at the ceremony
The internet ushered in a new era of communication
His discoveries ushered major advances in medical treatment worldwide

definitions: take a position of power or importance illegally or by force without right
examples: The general attempted to usurp control of the government
No one should usurp the authority of elected officials
She felt her colleague was trying to usurp her position
The new manager usurped responsibilities that weren't really his

definitions: make a sound with one's voice or speak words aloud
examples: She didn't utter a single word during the meeting
The baby uttered her first words at ten months
He uttered a cry of pain when he stubbed his toe
Don't utter another sound until I finish speaking please

definitions: leave a place that one previously occupied making it available for others
examples: Tenants must vacate the apartment by the end of month
The judge ordered everyone to vacate the courtroom immediately
Students vacate their dorms during summer break every year
Please vacate your hotel room before noon on checkout day

definitions: treat with a vaccine to produce immunity against a disease
examples: Parents should vaccinate their children according to medical guidelines
The clinic will vaccinate all employees against the flu
Veterinarians vaccinate pets to prevent common animal diseases yearly
Health workers vaccinate millions of people during disease outbreaks

definitions: clean carpets or floors using a vacuum cleaner machine
examples: She vacuums the living room carpet twice a week
Please vacuum under the sofa when you clean today
The janitor vacuums all office floors every evening after work
Don't forget to vacuum the stairs before guests arrive

definitions: park customers' cars as a professional service at hotels or restaurants
examples: The hotel staff will valet your car for a small fee
He works nights valeting cars at the fancy restaurant
Many upscale venues valet cars to provide convenience for guests
They valet hundreds of vehicles during busy weekend events downtown

definitions: check or prove the validity accuracy or truth of something
recognize or affirm that someone's feelings or opinions are worthwhile
examples: Please validate your parking ticket at the front desk
Scientists must validate their findings through repeated experiments
Good friends validate your feelings during difficult times together
The therapist validated her concerns about the stressful situation

definitions: play music especially jazz in an improvisational repetitive style
repair or replace the front upper part of a shoe
examples: The pianist vamped while waiting for the singer to begin
Jazz musicians often vamp between songs during live performances
The cobbler can vamp those old boots to look new
She learned to vamp shoes in her grandfather's repair shop

definitions: defeat an enemy or opponent completely in battle or competition
examples: The hero vanquished the dragon and saved the kingdom
Our team hopes to vanquish their rivals in tomorrow's game
She vanquished her fears and gave an excellent speech
The general vanquished enemy forces after a long campaign

definitions: inhale and exhale vapor from an electronic cigarette or similar device
examples: Many people vape instead of smoking traditional cigarettes now
She started to vape to help quit her smoking habit
Teenagers shouldn't vape despite thinking it's safer than smoking
He vapes flavored liquids that contain nicotine every day

definitions: apply a clear protective liquid coating to wood or other surfaces
examples: The carpenter will varnish the table after sanding it smooth
We need to varnish the deck before winter weather arrives
Artists often varnish paintings to protect and preserve them
She varnished the wooden jewelry box three times for shine

definitions: jump over something using hands or a pole for support
store valuable items in a secure room or container
examples: The athlete vaulted over the high bar with perfect form
She vaulted the fence to retrieve her lost ball quickly
Banks vault cash and important documents in secure rooms
The museum vaults priceless artifacts in climate controlled storage

definitions: change direction suddenly especially to avoid hitting something while moving
examples: The car veered sharply to avoid hitting the deer
The conversation veered away from politics to safer topics
The ship had to veer off course during the storm
His thoughts veered between hope and despair all day

definitions: cover something with a veil or thin material that obscures
examples: Some brides veil their faces during the wedding ceremony
Fog veiled the mountain peaks early this morning completely
She veiled her emotions behind a smile at the party
Curtains veil the windows for privacy from neighbors outside

definitions: cover wood or furniture with a thin decorative layer of fine material
examples: The carpenter will veneer the cabinet doors with oak
They veneer cheap wood to make it look more expensive
Dentists can veneer teeth to improve their appearance significantly
The company veneers particle board with attractive wood grain

definitions: regard with great respect reverence or devotion especially for age wisdom or character
examples: Many cultures venerate their elders for wisdom and experience
Catholics venerate saints through prayers and special feast days
The community venerates local heroes who served with distinction
Students venerate the professor for her groundbreaking research work

definitions: express one's feelings or opinions forcefully often to release frustration
provide an outlet or opening for air gas or liquid to pass
examples: She needed to vent her frustrations after the difficult meeting
Friends often vent to each other about work stress
Plumbers vent pipes to prevent dangerous gas buildup inside
The dryer vents hot air outside through a special duct

definitions: be very close to a particular state condition or situation
examples: The company verges on bankruptcy without immediate financial help
She was verging on tears during the emotional speech
His behavior verges on rudeness when he's stressed at work
The old building verges on collapse and needs immediate repair

definitions: give someone the legal right authority or power to do something
examples: The constitution vests certain powers in the executive branch
The court vests custody of children with their mother
Property rights vest immediately upon signing the legal documents
The board vests authority in the CEO to make decisions

definitions: make a careful examination or investigation of someone or something beforehand
examples: Companies vet job candidates through background checks and interviews
The committee will vet all proposals before making recommendations
Journalists should vet their sources before publishing sensitive stories
Security teams vet visitors before allowing access to secure areas

definitions: reject a decision or proposal using one's position of authority
examples: The president can veto bills passed by congress constitutionally
Parents often veto their children's unreasonable requests firmly
The board will veto any budget that exceeds available funds
She vetoed the dinner plans and suggested somewhere else

definitions: make someone feel annoyed frustrated or worried especially with trivial matters
examples: Traffic jams vex commuters trying to get home from work
Don't let small problems vex you throughout the day
The puzzle vexed her until she finally found the solution
His constant complaints vex everyone in the office daily

definitions: create or give off a particular feeling mood or atmosphere
relax and enjoy the atmosphere or feeling of a place
examples: The coffee shop vibes creativity with its artistic decorations
She vibes confidence whenever she enters a room
Let's just vibe at the beach this weekend together
They vibed to the music at the outdoor festival

definitions: move rapidly and continuously back and forth with small movements
examples: The phone vibrates when you receive a text message
Earthquakes cause the ground to vibrate beneath our feet
Guitar strings vibrate to produce different musical notes clearly
The washing machine vibrates loudly during the spin cycle

definitions: compete eagerly with someone to achieve or win something
examples: Several companies vie for the government contract every year
Athletes vie for gold medals at the Olympic games
The siblings constantly vie for their parents' attention daily
Politicians vie for votes during the election campaign season

definitions: clear someone of blame or suspicion by proving innocence
show or prove that someone or something is right justified or reasonable
examples: New evidence vindicated the wrongly accused man after years
The investigation vindicated her claims of workplace harassment completely
Time vindicated his controversial theories about climate change
The election results vindicated their campaign strategy perfectly

definitions: officially approve or stamp a passport allowing entry to a country
examples: The embassy will visa your passport within five business days
Officials visa thousands of documents during peak travel season
They visa applications after checking all required paperwork carefully
The consulate visas passports for tourists and business travelers

definitions: form a mental image or picture of something in one's mind
examples: Athletes visualize winning before important competitions to prepare mentally
Try to visualize yourself succeeding at the job interview
Architects visualize buildings before drawing the actual plans
She visualizes peaceful scenes to help manage stress effectively

definitions: create and post video blogs on the internet about various topics
examples: She vlogs about her travels to exotic destinations worldwide
Many teenagers vlog daily about their lives and interests
Professional creators vlog to build audiences and earn income
He started to vlog his cooking experiments last year

definitions: declare that something is legally invalid null or no longer binding
examples: The court will void the contract due to fraud
Banks void checks that have been altered or damaged
The warranty voids if you open the device yourself
Officials void election results when irregularities are discovered

definitions: hit or kick a ball before it touches the ground in sports
discharge or fire weapons rapidly at the same time
examples: The tennis player volleyed the ball across the net
Soccer players practice volleying balls during training sessions
Soldiers volleyed shots across the battlefield during the attack
The ships volleyed cannon fire at each other repeatedly

definitions: eject matter from the stomach through the mouth when sick
examples: The patient may vomit after taking this strong medication
Children often vomit when they have stomach flu
Motion sickness causes some people to vomit on boats
She had to vomit after eating the spoiled food

definitions: practice religious rituals involving magic charms and communication with spirits
examples: Some communities voodoo to heal illnesses and solve problems
Practitioners voodoo using dolls herbs and special ceremonies
They voodoo for protection against evil spirits and enemies
The priestess will voodoo to bring good fortune

definitions: make a solemn promise or commitment to do something
examples: Couples vow to love each other during wedding ceremonies
She vowed never to make the same mistake again
Politicians vow to serve their constituents faithfully when elected
He vowed revenge against those who wronged his family

definitions: go on a long journey especially by sea or in space
examples: Early explorers voyaged across unknown oceans seeking new lands
The cruise ship will voyage through the Caribbean islands
Astronauts voyage to the space station for research missions
They plan to voyage around the world next year

definitions: make or move with the loud deep sound of an engine
examples: Race cars vroom loudly as they speed around the track
The motorcycle vroomed past us on the empty highway
Kids vroom while playing with toy cars on the floor
He vroomed the engine to show off its power

definitions: compress soft material into a lump ball or bundle shape
examples: She wadded up the paper and threw it away
Don't wad your clothes when packing the suitcase
He wadded cotton into his ears to block noise
The child wadded clay into different shapes during art

definitions: walk with short steps swaying from side to side like a duck
examples: Penguins waddle across the ice on their short legs
The toddler waddled toward her mother with outstretched arms
Pregnant women sometimes waddle in their final months
Ducks waddle on land but swim gracefully in water

definitions: walk through water or another liquid that impedes normal movement
examples: Children love to wade in shallow pools during summer
We had to wade across the stream to continue hiking
Fishermen wade into rivers to reach the best spots
She waded through puddles on her way to work

definitions: speak or write at length without making clear points being evasive
examples: Politicians often waffle when asked difficult questions directly
Stop waffling and give me a straight answer please
He waffled through his presentation without reaching any conclusions
She tends to waffle instead of making firm decisions

definitions: move something rapidly back and forth or up and down
examples: Dogs wag their tails when they feel happy or excited
She wagged her finger at the naughty child disapprovingly
The puppy's tail never stops wagging around new people
He wagged his head to show disagreement with the plan

definitions: risk money on the outcome of an event or competition
examples: He likes to wager on horse races every weekend
I'll wager twenty dollars that our team wins tonight
Gamblers wager thousands at casino tables hoping to win
She wagered her entire savings on the risky investment
